children.subject: I didn't find that to be true, although I can see why people would feel that way. It's an algorithms class - you're going to be asked to design algorithms with a limited amount of time, which is challenging and can feel impossible to study for. But I thought many points on the exams were achievable without any "flashes of insight." And it was pretty clear what material was in-scope for any given exam. Just my experience, other people might have very different impressions

Also a question to tag along with the above:
I heard it's very difficult to study for the exams. How true are these claims?

history.content:
I took 176 last semester. The workload was extremely light. There were 5 problem sets with around 5 questions each, around the same type as 170.

There are biological motivations behind the algorithms, but the main thing for the class is learning algorithms. The 3 main areas we covered were string search algorithms (which are useful for things outside biology), phylogentic tree algorithms (which don't really have much of a use outside biology, or at least I haven't heard much about it), and hidden markov models (which definitely do have uses outside biology). Background information was given on why we would learn such algorithms and apply them to biology, but they weren't tested on.

Exams are fairly more difficult to prepare for as there aren't as many practice problems and past tests to go over. You maybe get 6-8 practice problems for each of the midterms and the final, where the exam would be 5 questions. The questions are around 80% prove this statement/design an algorithm to do this, and 20% mechanical problems such as apply this algorithm from the class on this input.

For anyone who has taken 176 before, how much bio is there? (I was looking for a more algorithms-focused course)

Also, how is the workload and difficulty compared to 170?

Thanks in advance.
history.subject: CS176
